p: A polypeptide (PEMP) extracted from Pleurotus eryngii (DC.) Quél. mycelium demonstrated significant free radical scavenging and antitumor activity in breast, cervical, and stomach cancer cells, whose growth it inhibited, and an activating effect on the macrophage-mediated immune response [ 36]. In a dose-dependent manner, it inhibited tumor cell proliferation, promoted macrophage proliferation and the expression of TNF- and IL-6 secretion, TLR2 and TLR4, and stimulated macrophage phagocytosis through the release of NO and H 2O 2. Cold-water extracts of P. eryngii var. ferulae (Lanzi) Sacc. and P. nebrodensis (Inzenga) Quél. showed marked in vitro anticancer activity on human HCT116 colon cancer cell lines [ 37]. Both treatments showed a marked inhibition of cancer cell viability and apoptosis induction, and a significant increase in the Bax/Bcl2 mRNA ratio; they also inhibited cell migration and affected homotypic and heterotypic cell–cell adhesion by inducing an increase in E-cadherin expression and negatively modulated the phosphorylation of both protein tyrosine and extracellular signal-regulated kinase ERK1/2.
